posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Davion from Team 2359,

As an initial member of your team, your focus on enhancing your CAD resources is commendable.

Your team's usage of CAD is restricted to specific parts for CNC milling and 3D printing. However, your objective is to integrate the entire robot into CAD during your tenure as a senior. This requires significant effort, especially since only you and two mentors are currently proficient in CAD. Teaching others could prove beneficial for the team's growth.

Given your experience with CAD, seeking advice, custom functions, resources, and tools would greatly assist your team in utilizing Onshape for FRC. While you are already utilizing Onshape4Frc and similar online tools, there may be additional functionalities or resources within Onshape that can enhance your team's capabilities. I encourage you to explore these opportunities to better support your team's goals.

Please let me know how I can contribute further.

Sincerely,
Davion

posts.name: Ari Davidson
posts.cooked: https://www.frcdesign.org/ is a really great resource if you aren’t already using it!

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: Thank you I had been planning on looking at it while at home since it’s blocked on the computers from our schools but had completely forgotten

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: You could look at onshape4frc.com in addition to frcdesign.org. It may have a few additional references.

posts.name: Benjamen Johnson
posts.cooked: Look at the slideshow on this thread. Here are the slides from the presentation I gave at FIRST Champs. I had a lot of questions about where they’d be posted, so here they are! The slides above are pretty similar to the ones I used at the NE Mentor Conference, so I’m curious if anyone has suggestions - should any topics be detailed further? Are there topics that should be added? There are a lot of good tips for organizing your robot and keeping the CAD speedy.

link_counts.title: CMP Conference Slides - Onshape Best Practices for FRC Design

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Okay, that looks really interesting, I'll look into it.

Thanks!!!

posts.name: Andrew Card
posts.cooked: Consider reaching out to your school's admin to ask if they can whitelist the site.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: Thank you! I hadn’t considered that yet. I will certainly try. I have quite a few websites I need white-listed, but our admin is stingy sometimes.

posts.name: Colin
posts.cooked: My team uses FRCDesign for training because it provides comprehensive CAD knowledge needed to create clean robots for FIRST Robotics Competition. We also utilize the MKCad Library for importing commercial parts and rely on Featurescripts from FRCDesign for additional tools.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked:
Thank you for your reply  
I will look into FRCDesign certainly and also check into whether it’s blocked on school Chromebooks  

I’ll look into the featurescripts included as well thank you  

I’m curious about how your team organizes projects in Onshape for collaboration between members? Currently we have a classroom or team setup but when a student adds a document no other students can view it except the classroom leader

posts.name: Colin
posts.cooked: Right now, we have a team set up that we’ve shared with our design team and any others who need access. We plan to establish a team account with the school to create a classroom for easier document management, as our current system has documents owned by an alum via their school email, posing risks of deletion.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: That answers my question perfectly, thank you!

posts.name: Colin
posts.cooked: Of course! Let me know if you have any other questions.

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: The other advantage to using a classroom is that it allows members to use other features, such as simulation and release management.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: Out of curiosity, I wonder if that feature is included with the free education package? Since we use free student and educator accounts, we aren't getting some of the professional features.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked: This blog details the benefits of using an educator plan and explains how to set it up, such as the Onshape Educator Plan for FIRST Robotics Teams. The most important reason is it can prevent situations where students graduate and leave with designs the team wants to keep.

link_counts.title: Onshape Educator Plan for FIRST Robotics Teams

posts.name: Calvin Selin
posts.cooked: Check out this thread: https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/onshape-educator-plan-what-it-means-for-frc-teams/446394

link_counts.title: Onshape Educator Plan: What it Means for FRC Teams

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: I’m reading through it currently. I believe our mentor has an educator plan, although I don’t think we’ve utilized its full potential. The blog contains a wealth of information.

posts.name: Davion Ortiz
posts.cooked: I'm reading through this as well!! Thanks!! (Is it mere coincidence that the writer of that thread also just sent a message? If so, that’s really cool)

posts.name: Julian Fernandez
posts.cooked: EXTRAordinarily important: Frcdesign covers most of what you need, but I’ll add a few key points. Good sketching skills are crucial—they form the foundation of all subsequent work. Don’t skip cleaning up sketches with lingering lines. Next, focus on features, using as few as possible and a variety to avoid typical pitfalls. Explore featurescripts wisely, saving time instead of wasting it. Create a library of essential tools for efficiency. Finally, tailor your approach based on your capabilities. Avoid being the design lead for something overly ambitious.
